prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

head.headtext: Factors articulated by the Panel in selecting transferee district—Overall experience of judge

para.paratext: The Panel has repeatedly indicated its preference for transferring multidistrict cases to courts with experience handling complex cases.[1] This factor is rarely the primary basis for selecting a transferee district, but it may be an important factor in the selection decision. This factor is more important, however, on the question of selecting a specific judge rather than a judicial district.[2] Because the availability of a judge experienced in the management of complex litigation is important to the Panel, it may affect the transfer decision itself[3] or the selection of a district.[4] This factor is discussed in greater detail in Chapter 7.

This factor is a difficult one for the parties to advance. By implication, it requires the suggestion that the judge or judges in alternative transferee districts are not as capable of handling the litigation. The Panel has rejected arguments concerning this factor and found them “wholly without merit.”[5] Experience handling similar MDL dockets can be particularly persuasive, and may be something more readily advanced by a party.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

See, e.g., In re Bayer Healthcare LLC and Merial Limited Flea Control Products Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 844 F. Supp. 2d 1369 (J.P.M.L. 2012); In re National Football League Players' Concussion Injury Litigation, 842 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2012); In re A-Power Energy Generation Systems, Ltd. Securities Litigation, 829 F. Supp. 2d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Imprelis Herbicide Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 825 F. Supp. 2d 1357 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Wesson Oil Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 818 F. Supp. 2d 1383 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Citimortgage, Inc., Home Affordable Modification Program (HAMP) Contract Litigation, 816 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Dial Complete Marketing Sales Practices Litigation, 804 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Bank of America Credit Protection Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 804 F. Supp. 2d 1372 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Zimmer Nexgen Knee Implant Products Liability Litigation, 802 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Google Android Consumer Privacy Litigation, 802 F. Supp. 2d 1372 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Certainteed Fiber Cement Siding Litigation, 802 F. Supp. 2d 1369 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Jiffy Lube International, Inc., Text Spam Litigation, 802 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Ampicillin Antitrust Litigation, 315 F. Supp. 317 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
This factor is discussed as a factor affecting selection of the transferee judge in §§ 7:6 and 7:11.
In re Ampicillin Antitrust Litigation, 315 F. Supp. 317 (J.P.M.L. 1970).

See, e.g., In re Intern. Air Transp. Surcharge Antitrust Litigation, 460 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2006) (judge experienced in MDL and complex litigation); In re Celexa and Lexapro Products Liability Litigation, 416 F. Supp. 2d 1361 (J.P.M.L. 2006) (experienced MDL judge); In re Vitamin C Antitrust Litigation, 416 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (J.P.M.L. 2006) (judge with MDL experience); In re Viagra Products Liability Litigation, 414 F. Supp. 2d 1357 (J.P.M.L. 2006) (where actions geographically dispersed, transfer to district with judge experienced in MDL actions); In re Panty Hose Seaming Patent Litigation, 402 F. Supp. 1401, 1403 (J.P.M.L. 1975) (availability of judge apparently primary factor in selecting district); In re IBM, 302 F. Supp. 796, 800 (J.P.M.L. 1969); In re Koratron, 302 F. Supp. 239 (J.P.M.L. 1969); In re Antibiotic Drugs, 295 F. Supp. 1402, 1403 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
See In re Tenneco Inc. Securities Litigation, 426 F. Supp. 1187, 1189 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
